DOMINION OF CANADA.

GOVERNMENT HOUSE, OTTAWA,
Monday, the 8th day of September, 1884.

PRESENT:

His Excellency the Governor General, in Council,

WHEREAS, the Honourable Mr. Justice Macdonald, of the Supreme Court of Canada, has been appointed by Her Majesty the Queen to be Judge of the Court of Queen's Bench for the District of Prince Albert, and has been sworn into office at Ottawa on the 7th instant; and whereas, the said Judge Macdonald has been requested by the Minister of Justice to take charge of the administration of justice in the said District;

NOW, THEREFORE, be it resolved by this Council, that the said Judge Macdonald be and he is hereby requested to take charge of the administration of justice in the said District, and that he be and he is hereby directed to perform all such duties as may be required of him in connection therewith.

TENDERS FOR FLOUR.

SEALED TENDERS will be received, addressed to the undersigned, before noon on the 25th of October, for the supply of flour, in good order and condition, of the following quantities (if offered), to be delivered to the Agent General's Office, Prince Albert, on or before the date hereafter mentioned, at the prices and conditions stated:

At Battleford, March 1st, 1885, 500 sacks.
At Fort Pitt, March 1st, 1885, 1,100 sacks.
At Caribou, March 1st, 1885, 500 sacks.
At Garrison, December 1st, 1884, 2,000 sacks.

The tenders must be signed by the owner or his agent, and must state the quantity, price per sack, and the name of the owner or his agent.

Tenders stating the price per sack to be made upon samples which may be shown to the Agent General's Office, Prince Albert, and at the Indian Offices at Battleford and Fort Pitt, and at the Garrison Office, Caribou.

The Agent General reserves the right to reject any tenders.

J. ANDREWS, Manager.
Indian Office, Caribou, N.W.T., Oct. 1, 1884.

THE EXHIBITION.

On Thursday morning, a full house assembled at the Law Courts to witness the opening of the Exhibition. The exhibition was opened by His Excellency the Governor General, who delivered an address to the assembled crowd. The exhibition was officially opened by His Excellency the Governor General, who delivered an address to the assembled crowd.

TELEGRAFIC.

By Special Telegraph to The Times.

OTTAWA, Oct. 12th.—Governor Cleveland was assassinated on the morning of the 12th inst. by a man named Samuel Beal, who was arrested by the Capitol Police.

Official returns announce a large return of votes for the late election.

The Hon. Mr. Justice Macdonald, of the Supreme Court of Canada, has been appointed Judge of the Court of Queen's Bench for the District of Prince Albert.

Mr. Justice Macdonald has been sworn into office at Ottawa on the 7th instant.

Mr. Justice Macdonald has been requested by the Minister of Justice to take charge of the administration of justice in the said District.

NOW, THEREFORE, be it resolved by this Council, that the said Judge Macdonald be and he is hereby requested to take charge of the administration of justice in the said District, and that he be and he is hereby directed to perform all such duties as may be required of him in connection therewith.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our reporter.

British Guyana has sent a visit to its store.

Sub-Agent Agent Marcus was in town yesterday.

Mr. Campbell received a large quantity of oil at this week.

The sky was illuminated by pyrotechnics last evening.

Mr. Miller's hall was deserted and no one was playing the fiddle.

G. & E. Carter have just received a lot of hucksters, Tables, Chairs, etc.

Mr. McMillan, Hat Portage, a brother-in-law of Middleton, of this place, is here on a visit.

The Curling Club are having the rink fixed up, and getting ready for the season.

POLICE NEWS.

John Monkman, a prisoner at the Barrack awaiting trial, was released before Hon. L. Clarke, J.P., on Thursday afternoon, having stolen a cow the property of Mr. Smith, of the parish, and was committed for trial.

Eliza Daugherty, at present awaiting her trial for horse stealing, took things into her own hands, and, when asked why John Monkman prefers fresh air and work, answered: How else that morning in Carleton, with Cone, Valdast and Col. Col. Irvine, Commissioner of the Police, is expected here next week.

The new building is now completed and ready for occupation.

The parties on the top floor have removed, and it now makes a splendid dormitory.

A guard house has been erected, capable of holding six prisoners, and is of substantial build.

Capt. Smith with about twenty men, will be stationed at the new guard house for the quarter. The Capt. will return two days from today, leaving the men in charge of Mr. Smith.

Mr. Smith, Capt. Smith, Mr. Ross, and Mr. Smith, have been engaged in the construction and installation of the new building, and it will be completed in a few days.

The new building will be a credit to the town as well as to the government in charge of the work.
NOTICE.

We beg the attention of the public to the fact that our financial year comes to an end upon the last day of this month (31st Oct.) and that in consequence of the same, we have nothing to offer them but what will be found in our usual manner. We therefore request that no one shall settle their accounts with us before the 31st Oct., and that all who have claims against us. Prompt attention to these matters will save us a great deal of trouble and inconvenience.

OUR SITUATION.

It is to be feared that the farmers of our district are by no means prepared to meet the difficulties which those resources which must result from the almost universal failure of the grain crops this year—for that such failure has happened there can no longer be any doubt. The season will be remembered as one of very natural but not the least unfortunate state of things, by those who from self-interested motives, desire to divert the stream of immigration from our shores, is so well evident; that it becomes impossible to point out to any one, that while circumstances may not unfairly be charged to our settlers, there is not the faintest evidence in this to detract from all that has been claimed for the natural advantages of the climate and soil of our region. We cannot without hesitation that had our farmers exercised a reasonable economy and foresight in the management of their affairs, they would, taking into consideration, have been in a position to lay by a good store of grain at this season, if not with perfect economy, at any rate with out alarm. To make an exhaustive catalogue of all the available errors which have landed us in this situation, again would be useless; we would only say, that we have been in a position to lay by a good store of grain at this season, if not with perfect economy, at any rate with out alarm.

The following have been appointed Justices of the Peace:—James Anderson, Thomas, Charles, Robert, Ross, John D. Urquhart, John F. Dewar, Samuel Ross, and John P. Clarke, Clark's Crossing.

CALGARY
From the North-West.
We are pleased to learn that some check is to be placed upon the pernicious Governor Dufferin's infamous habit of borrowing money from anyone to anyone unknown to himself, unless recommended by the commanding officer of the regiment.

Mr. Hugh, High River, arrived from the Coal Banks with 1,200 sheep on Tuesday last week.

Frank Smith, who came here in anticipation of the Selkirk, has sold half interest in two of his lands for $5,000.

Mr. D. McPhail, Morley, had some sixty acres of land with crops, and was granted a few acres more. An inspection of the land the other day failed to discover any sign of life among the Hungry Indians found on both sides of the river.

HATFIELD
From the World, Oct. 17.
Inspector Antonius has been made Superintendent and stationed at Regina.

Mr. Wadsworth, Inspector of Indian Agencies, arrived here yesterday evening, the 16th, on his annual tour of inspection.

The sum of $130 was subscribed the other day to defray the expense of boiling water for the Indians, who are supplied with part of the town with water.

At a public meeting on the 9th the project of surveying a half mile wide strip of land along the line of the railway was discussed. The amount of $130 was taken by those present, and a committee appointed to secure the necessary authority. It is expected any one will undertake the erection this fall. If the result of these enquiries is satisfactory, the Provincial Government will be asked to carry out the scheme.

Mrs. J. M. Rae returned on the 10th from a visit to her relatives.

Mrs. Gardner, wife of G. W. Gardner, of the Indian office, and children, arrived from Mackenzie (River on the 10th) and will settle here.

Mrs. Gardner returned from Ontario on the 7th, accompanied by her brother and sister, Mr. and Miss Jackson.

REGINA
From the Leader, Oct. 18.
His Honour Lord Governor Dewdney left on Saturday morning to visit the Indian Agencies—i.e., Indian Commissioner—in the South and other north country districts.

The Rev. Father Larche is at present doing missionary work along the line of the go go district under the charge of Mr. John Barn Dalgliesh, Long Lake, has been appointed a magistrate and a J.P.

The first annual exhibition of the Assiniboia Agricultural Society, was held here on the 2nd and 3rd inst., and was a most enjoyable affair.

The Hon. Donald A. Smith has purchased the prize Highland bull at the Highland Society's show in Scotland, and has sent him to Regina. He will be used for breeding for his estate at Silver Heights.

Arrangements are being made for proper packing and shipping of grain for our farmers. The province is now ripe for harvest, and the grain of the farms and lands of Chicago will be marketed in our North West, and another staple will be forever dropped from our rapidly decreasing list.

PORT MACQUARIE
From the Courier, Oct. 18.
The sale of the police hall began yesterday morning. A big price was realised.

Sunday night there were thirteen tons of grain at the Cochran Ranch, and Monday night there were an equal amount of grain. We understand that a portion of the crop on Finster Creek was not saved, but that the remainder of the crop was saved, and will be marketed at a good price.

Monday, Jan. 20, and Tuesday, Jan. 21, will be the last days where grain fails to ripen this year; it was put too late.

Masons: Jar. Goddard and Poveshull joined on June 1st last Saturday and left for the Cochran Ranch on Sunday morning.

Dr. Schultz
To Arrive in the City This Evening.

Something about him. A letter from John Bruce, who figured here during the Rebellion of 1885, has just been received in our office. No detail was said about what was done with the body.

Western, October 8 - A telegram was received here yesterday by Mr. Wm. McGregor from Dr. Schultz who was in Minneapolis on his way to Winnipeg. The telegram announced that the symbol might be expected at early hour today. Mr. McGregor was born in Western Ontario, and at an early age began attending Victoria College for his medical training. He graduated there, receiving licentiate of M.D., in 1863. He visited the Red River settlement in 1872, shortly after the outbreak then affecting public opinion with the country and its resources, and convinced others that following the profession began in a manner than it had hitherto. He became impressed with the country where he resided, and continued there for many years, finally moving to Winnipeg. His opinions prevailed during the relations of that time, and he supported the movement which led him to live in Canada. He was here for two and a half years, when Wm. Hacking joined him, and they again returned to Europe. He continued, the ensuing ten years, and proved himself very able man, and was elected president of the Club. Upon the death of his wife, he returned to England, and died there in 1890.
